thread.title: Free training in Lady Lake protects citizens from online scams
thread.title_full: Free training in Lady Lake protects citizens from online scams

author: Julie Garisto
title: Free training in Lady Lake protects citizens from online scams
text:
Free cyber training arms citizens against theft and other threats
Julie Garisto
- The Town of Lady Lake is offering a free cybersecurity training session for residents.
- The event was organized in response to recent scams targeting local pensioners.
- Security Analyst Howard Davis will teach attendees how to spot digital threats and protect personal information.
- The session will take place at the Lady Lake Library on January 29 at 2 p.m.
The Town of Lady Lake is hosting a public event to educate residents on how to protect themselves from digital threats.
The cybersecurity training session has been launched after a series of scams targeted pensioners, a media release said.
Several local pensioners have recently been tricked into sending money to imposters by fraudsters who contacted them online or by phone.
Lady Lake Security Analyst Howard Davis will lead the session at the Lady Lake Library, 225 W. Guava St., Room 219, at 2 p.m. on Jan. 29. It is designed for computer users of all skill levels.
Davis will break down the most common types of social engineering and explain how cybercriminals use deceptive tactics to gain access to personal or financial information.
Attendees also will learn best practices for creating strong, secure passwords and safeguarding information across digital platforms.
"This session is designed to help you build confidence in spotting potential cyber threats before they become a serious problem," Davis said in the media release, adding that attendees will learn essential safety practices and simple protective measures that can make a big difference in keeping personal information secure.
The free session will include real-world examples. To register, visit bit.ly/LLCyberTraining.
This story was created by reporter Julie Garisto, jgaristo@USATodayco.com, assigned to create this story with the assistance of Artificial Intelligence (Al). Journalists were involved in every step of the information gathering, review, editing and publishing process. Learn more at cm.usatoday/ethical-conduct.
